metadata.case_name: Union of India v. Respondent (Consignee to Baidyanathdham)

facts.text: 60 bales of piece goods consigned from Wadibundar to Baidyanathdham, loaded in wagon No. 9643 on December 1, 1947.
Consignment reached Mughalsarai on the morning of December 9, 1947 by 192 Dn goods train.
Wagon kept in marshalling yard at Mughalsarai till December 12, 1947.
Wagon sent to Baidyanathdham by 214 Dn goods train from Mughalsarai at 6:40 p.m. on December 12, 1947, reached Baidyanathdham on December 21, 1947.
Respondent presented railway receipt on December 21, 1947; railway delivered 29 bales, 31 bales missing and never delivered.
Notice under s.80 CPC given on August 31, 1948; suit filed on November 20, 1948 for Rs. 36,461/12/- damages due to non-delivery from misconduct.
Consignment booked under risk note form Z (similar to form B), at specially reduced rate.
Railway's defence: theft in running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar on December 12, 1947; full disclosure made in written statement.
Notice dated April 10, 1948 to Chief Commercial Manager, E.I.R., stating 60 bales booked, 29 delivered, 31 not, claiming Rs. 36,461/12/- if not delivered in fortnight.
Trial court (Additional Subordinate Judge) dismissed suit: no notice under s.77 needed for non-delivery; no proof of misconduct under risk note Z.
High Court (Patna, First Appeal No. 340 of 1951) allowed appeal, decreed suit with costs: breach of disclosure condition in risk note Z, liability as simple bailee, no proper care at Mughalsarai.
Wagon arrived intact at Mughalsarai; evidence of Damodar Prasad Sharma (P.W.14) on receipt; no untoward entry.
Evidence of Chatterji (P.W.8): wagon in good condition when dispatched on Dec 12; rivets/seals checked by watch and ward staff.

Guard Ram Prasad Ram (P.W.2): patrolled train, seals/rivets intact at Mughalsarai departure; train stopped between Warner and home signals before Dildarnagar due to hosepipe disconnect; noticed northern flap door open, rivets/seals broken on one side; escorts guarding; reported at Dildarnagar.
At Dildarnagar: northern flap doors open, southern intact with original seals; wagon resealed (guard says rivetted too, but entry only resealed).
At Buxar: northern flap doors open; resealed and rivetted; detached for checking on Dec 14: 27 bales intact, one covering torn, one loose; one side original Wadibundar seals, other Buxar seals.
No demand by respondent for disclosure before suit or during trial for watch and ward staff or seal book from Mughalsarai.

legal_issues.text: Whether notice under s.77 of the Indian Railways Act was necessary and given for non-delivery of goods.
Whether railway complied with disclosure obligation under risk note form Z proviso (cl. a for non-delivery); effect of any breach; whether misconduct of railway servants proved.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit barred by s.77 Railways Act as no notice given for non-delivery (treated as loss).
Under risk note Z, railway absolved unless misconduct proved by respondent; full disclosure made in written statement; loss due to theft in running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar, no misconduct.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Risk note form Z; Surat Cotton Spinning case (Privy Council)

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if breach of disclosure, risk note continues; misconduct not inferred; respondent failed to prove misconduct or demand further evidence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.72 Railways Act; s.114 Evidence Act

respondent_arguments.text: No notice under s.77 needed for non-delivery (distinct from loss).
Railway breached disclosure condition in risk note Z; thus risk note inapplicable, liability as simple bailee under s.72(1); no proper care at Mughalsarai, seals/rivets broken there.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Risk note Z proviso; s.72(1) Railways Act

court_reasoning.text: Non-delivery is consequence of loss; notice under s.77 necessary; April 10, 1948 letter sufficient notice under s.77 as it gave all particulars within 6 months.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overruled Patna view per Governor-General v. Musaddilal; followed Jetmull Bhojraj.

court_reasoning.text: Risk note Z applies even if disclosure breach; disclosure obligation arises on request pre-litigation or in suit; no pre-suit request; in suit, no demand for further evidence (e.g., watch and ward staff); no breach by railway.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Followed Privy Council in Surat Cotton: breach does not end risk note; misconduct more readily inferred but not here.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence (guard, clerks, station staff) shows wagon intact at Mughalsarai departure; theft in running train between Mughalsarai-Buxar; no fair inference of misconduct at Mughalsarai; respondent led no evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Guard's evidence reliable; no adverse inference without demand for further evidence.

holdings.text: Notice under s.77 necessary for non-delivery and sufficiently given via April 10, 1948 letter.
Risk note Z governs; no breach of disclosure by railway; no misconduct inferred from evidence or presumed; burden on respondent not discharged.

precedents_cited.relevance: Non-delivery amounts to loss; s.77 notice necessary, overruling Patna High Court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jetmull Bhojraj v. The Darjeeling Himalayan Railway Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Letter with particulars sufficient as s.77 notice even if not labelled as such.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surat Cotton Spinning Weaving Mills v. Secretary Of State for India in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Disclosure obligation under risk note B/Z; arises on request; breach does not void risk note, allows ready inference of misconduct or s.114 Evidence Act presumption.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railways Act, 1890
statutes_cited.relevance: s.77: notice for loss/non-delivery; s.72: bailee liability, limitable by approved risk notes like Z.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Railway liability as bailee, subject to limitations.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption against party not producing evidence, applicable post-disclosure.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment and decree, restored trial court's dismissal of suit. No liability on railway under risk note Z as no misconduct proved.

key_quotes.text: "failure to deliver goods is the consequence of loss or destruction and the cause of action for it is not distinct from the cause of action for loss or destruction"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holding on s.77 notice necessity for non-delivery.

key_quotes.text: "even if there is a breach of the term as to full disclosure it does not bring the contract to an end and throw the responsibility on the railway as if the case was a simple case of responsibility under s.72(1)"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key interpretation of risk note effect despite disclosure breach.

key_quotes.text: "the responsibility of the railway administration to disclose... arises at once under the agreement... but such disclosure is necessary only where the consignor specifically asks"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies timing and trigger for disclosure obligation.
